lines.text: [Rod has just told Jerry he will keep him as his agent]
That's, that's great. I'm very... happy.
Are you listenin'?
Yes!
God bless you, Jerry. But this is what you gonna do for me. You listenin', Jerry?
Yeah, what, what, what can I do for you, Rod? You just tell me what can I do for you?
It's a very personal, a very important thing. Hell, it's a family motto. Are you ready, Jerry?
I'm ready.
Show me the money. Oh-ho-ho! SHOW! ME! THE! MONEY! A-ha-ha! Jerry, doesn't it make you feel good just to say that! Say it with me one time, Jerry.
Show you the money.
Oh, no, no. You can do better than that, Jerry! I want you to say it with you, with meaning, brother! Hey, I got Bob Sugar on the other line; I bet you he can say it!
Yeah, yeah, no, no, no. Show you the money.
No! Not show you! Show me the money!
Show me the money!
Yeah! Louder!
Show me the money!
Yes, but, brother, you got to yell that shit!
Show me the money!
I need to feel you, Jerry!
Show me the money!
Jerry, you got to yell!

[screaming]
Show me the money! Show me the money!
Do you love this black man!
I love the black man! Show me the money!
I love black people.
I love black people!
Who's your motherfucker, Jerry?
You're my motherfucker!
Whatcha gonna do, Jerry?
Show me the money!
Unh! Congratulations, you're still my agent.

[babbling and struggling]
I love you. You... you complete me. And I just...
Shut up,
[pause]
just shut up.
[Pause]
You had me at "hello". You had me at "hello".
If this
[points to heart]
is empty, this
[points to head]
doesn't matter.
Success consists of simply getting up one more time than you fall.
I love him! I love him for the man he wants to be. And I love him for the man he almost is.
The fuckin zoo is closed, Ray.
You said fuck.
Uh... yeah... I...
Don't worry. I won't tell.
I am out here for you. You don't know what it's like to be ME out here for YOU. It is an up-at-dawn, pride-swallowing siege that I will never fully tell you about, ok?
Show me the money!
D'you know that the human head weighs 8 pounds?
Did you know that Troy Aikman, in only six years, has passed for 16,303 yards?
D'you know that bees and dogs can smell fear?
Did you know that the career record for hits is 4,256 by Pete Rose who is NOT in the Hall of Fame?
D'you know that my next door neighbor has three rabbits?
I... I can't compete with that!
Maybe you don't. Because it's not just the money I deserve. It's not just the "coin." It's the... - "the kwan".
That's your word?
Yeah, man, it means love, respect, community... and the dollars too. The package. The kwan.
But how did you get "kwan?"
I got there from "coin," dude. Coin, coin... kwaaaan.
Help me... help you. Help me, help you.
[after Tidwell makes a good play on TV]
Yeah! That's my mo-fo!
[gasps]

[suddenly guilty]
Oops.
Uh-uh. Come here.
[does, a bit scared]
How about you be the first man in the family to stop using that phrase, and then maybe we'll let you live.
What do you want from me? My soul?
Why not? I deserve that much.

But if anybody else wants to come with me, this moment will be the ground floor of something real and fun and inspiring and true in this godforsaken business and we will do it together! Who's coming with me besides... "Flipper" here?
[last lines]
Hey, I don't have all the answers. In life, to be honest, I failed as much as I have succeeded. But I love my wife. I love my life. And I wish you my kind of success.

I will not rest until I have you holding a Coke, wearing your own shoe, playing a Sega game *featuring you*, while singing your own song in a new commercial, *starring you*, broadcast during the Superbowl, in a game that you are winning, and I will not *sleep* until that happens. I'll give you fifteen minutes to call me back.
I feel for you, man. But a real man wouldn't shoplift the pootie from a single mom.
I didn't shoplift the pootie.
[Rod gives him a long Look]
All right. I shoplifted the pootie.
The key to this business is personal relationships.
What are you doing with me, Rod?
Why?
Because a hockey player's kid made me feel like a superficial jerk. I ate two slices of bad pizza, went to bed and grew a conscience!
Well, boo-fucking-hoo
Have you ever gotten the feeling that you aren't completely embarassed yet, but you glimpse tomorrow's embarrassment?
I just want to be inspired.
This is going to change everything.
Promise?

[shouting, to Jerry]
What do you stand for?

How about a little piece of integrity in this world that is so full of greed and a lack of honorability that I don't know what to tell my son! Except, "Here. Have a look at a guy who isn't yelling 'Show me the money." Did you know he's broke? He is broke and working for you for free! Broke. Broke, broke, broke. I'm sorry I'm just not as good at the insults as she is.
No, that was pretty good.
I am a valuable commodity! I go across the middle! I see a dude coming at me, trying to kill me, I tell myself "Get killed. Catch the ball!' BOO YA! Touchdown! I make miracles happen!
Rod...
I'm from Arizona, Jerry! I broke Arizona records! I went to Arizona State! I'm a Sun Devil, man!
And now you want Arizona dollars?
Exaaaacctly!
Don't worry, I'm not gonna do what you all think I'm gonna do, which is, you know, FLIP OUT!
A positive anything is better than a negative nothing.
Dig the well before you are thirsty.
I don't like black people? I am Mister black people.
Anyone else would have left you by now, but I'm sticking with you. And if I have to ride your ass like Zorro, you're gonna show me the money.
I'm still sort of moved by your "My word is stronger than oak" thing.
You fuck this up, I'll kill you!
I'm glad we had this talk.
You are hanging on by a very thin thread and I dig that about you!
That's how you become great, man. Hang your balls out there!
Maybe love shouldn't be such hard work.
Jump in my nightmare, the water's warm!
I'm sorry, I'm just not as good at the insults as she is.
No, that was pretty good.
No shit.
[Jerry Maguire is lying in bed one morning when suddenly the radio comes on and wakes him up with a jolt]
[flash to Dickey Fox in his office]
I love the mornings! I clap my hands every morning and say, 'This is gonna be a great day!'
[flash back to Jerry Maguire who accidentally steps on a toy]

[mutters]
I don't believe this. How'd I get myself into this?
Don't cry at the beginning of a date. Cry at the end, like I do.
On the surface, everything seems fine. I've got this great guy. And he loves my kid. And he sure does like me a lot. And I can't live like that. It's not the way I'm built.
I got a shelf life of ten years, tops. My next contract's gotta bring me the dollars that'll last me and mine a long time. Shit, I'm out of this sport in 5 years. What's my family gonna live on? Huh?

[upon seeing the fax]
1.5 million? Man, we owe more than that!
How's your head?
Bubblicious.

There is a sensitivity thing that some people have. I don't have it. I don't cry at movies, I don't gush over babies, I don't buy Christmas presents 5 months early, and I DON'T tell the guy who just ruined both our lives, "Oh, poor baby." But I do love you.
There is no real loyalty, and the first person who taught me that was you.
I figure I was trying to sleep with you at the time.
Well, it worked.
[Dorothy enters kitchen, catching Laurel eavesdropping]
I heard.
No kidding. I looked over and saw the shadow of two curious shoes under the kitchen door.
Dorothy, this guy would go home with a gardening tool if it showed interest.
He's coming over.
Tonight?
He just lost his best client. I invited the guy over.

Dorothy, this is not a guy. It's a syndrome. Early mid-life. Hanging on to the bottom rung. "Dear God, don't let me be alone or I call my newly-long-suffering-assistant-without-medical for company settlement." If now all you still want is him to come over, I'm not saying anything.
Honey, he's engaged.
You see this jacket I'm wearing, you like it? Because I don't really need it, because I'm cloaked in failure!
I won't let you get rid of me.
Show me the money!
[Looking over an inadequate contract]
I'll go back to them.
And say what? "Please remove your dick from my ass"?
I'm sorry, I'm just a little pregnant here.
I was inspired, and I'm an accountant.

[to Jerry]
What you do have is my whole word, and it's stronger than oak.
[shakes Jerry's hand]
I hated myself... no, I hated my place in the world.

Jerry Maguire... How'm I doing? I'm sweating, dude! I'm sweatin' my contract! I'm sweating Bob Sugar calling me, telling me I'm missing the big endorsements by being with you! THAT'S how I'm doing - I'm sweating, dude!
[Jerry and Dorothy are in the elevator and a hearing impaired couple gets on. The man of the couple starts talking with his hands, then they get off]
I wonder what he just said.
My favorite aunt is hearing impaired. He just said "You complete me".
I started talking to Dennis Wilburn about your re-negotiation this morning.
Talking. Jerry Rice, Andre Reed, Chris Carter... I smell all these fools. They are making the big sweet dollars. They are making the... quan, and you are talking.
You tell me to eat lima beans, I'll eat lima beans
Quit using that word. "Quan", that's my word!
You're my ambassador of quawn, man.
You bet on me like I bet on you.
[first lines]
So this is the world, and there are almost six billion people on it. When I was a kid, there were three. It's hard to keep up.
We live in a cynical world. A cynical world. And we work in a business of tough competitors. I love you. You... complete me.
Rod, think about back when you were a little kid. It wasn't about the money, was it? Was it?
[Questionably]
Was it?
No, I air-dry.
Everybody loves you. Pisses me off.
I'm not trying to make history here.
I'm incapable of small talk.
Who's your motherfucker?
You're my motherfucker!
I have this great guy. And he loves my son. And he sure does like me a lot.
You are Jerry Ma-fucken-guire!
Jerry Maguire, my agent. You're my ambassador of Kwan.
Is it my imagination or, didn't we arrive in a limo?
What's wrong, Mommy?
First class, that's what's wrong. It used to be a better meal, now it's a better life.
That's more than a dress. That's an Audrey Hepburn movie.
[Having sex with Jerry Maguire]
Don't ever stop fucking me!

If you ever want me to be with another woman for you, I'd do it. It's not something I'm interested in. Once, yeah, it seemed normal, but it was just a phase, a college thing, like torn Levi's or law school for you. Would you like something from the kitchen? I'm gonna get some fruit.
I've had three lovers in the past four years, and they all ran a distant second to a good book and a warm bath.
Thanks for coming.
I missed ya. What can I say? You're all I've got.

[Over the phone]
Tell me you got lost on your way to the restaurant because I know you wouldn't stand up a friend
Something came up

[Referring to Rod's contract]
ten million dollars for four years
It's early, your still dreaming
Ten for four and it's a deal
The guy's got an attitude problem
I can help you with that he listens to me
His a shrimp
He broke every receiving record you had last year
I want a prototypical wide receiver I want someone who is six foot three inches tall, two thundered twenty pounds not someone who's five ten and bitches in the locker room
I'm asking you for a favor I introduced you to your wife, we've spent Christmases together
You're reaching
Don't do this, we have history
Yeah we have history, you've drove up the prices on me for years and now it's time for you to spend some time at the back of the line.
It's not "show friends." It's show *business*.
Look at me Laurel, I'm the oldest 26 year old in the world.

[about everyone being so shocked at her anger]
Well, I'm sorry but please remove your dick from my ass!
Ya know! Ya know! We're together on this one! Ya know! Ya know!
Oh my god.

[to Rod]
I'll tell you why you don't have your ten million dollars. Because right now, you are a paycheck player, you play with your head and not your heart, your personal life is all heart but when you get on the field, it's all about what you didn't get, who's to blame, who under threw the pass, who's got the contracts you don't, who's not giving you your love. That's not what inspires people. Just shut up and play the game with your heart.

in a single game. I also signed Erica Sorgi, you'll see her in the next Olympics. In Seattle I signed Dallas Malloy, she's sixteen years old and her lawsuit helped paved the way for women boxers everywhere, whenever she fights she thinks about her ex-boyfriend. In Indio, California I signed Art Stallings he plays the sport with what pure joy. In Odessa, Texas I signed the great Frank Cushman this April twenty six teams will be falling all over themselves in order to sign him in the next NFL draft his my client, my most important client, believe me there's genius everywhere but until they turn pro it's like popcorn in the pan some pop, some don't
